item.title: Thought: Links vs. Tags
item.description:
Quick observation while organizing notes today:

Tags = “this note is about X” Links = “this note relates to that specific note”

Tags create broad buckets. Links create specific bridges.

I’ve been over-using tags when I should be linking. A note about [[Spaced Repetition]] doesn’t just need the tag “learning” - it needs a direct link to [[Progressive Summarization]] because they’re related techniques.

The [[Note-Taking|knowledge graph]] shows this clearly: tags create dense clusters, links create meaningful paths between clusters.

Morning

Wrote [[Thought: Links vs. Tags]] after yesterday’s cleanup. The distinction is clearer now:

  • Tags = broad categorization
  • Links = specific relationships

Afternoon

The knowledge base feels alive now. When I open a note, the backlinks show me connections I forgot I made. Exactly what [[How to Take Smart Notes|Ahrens]] describes.

What’s Working

  • Daily notes as an entry point
  • MOCs as navigation hubs
  • The [[Note-Taking|graph]] for serendipitous discovery

What Needs Work

  • More permanent notes (too many fleeting ones)
  • Better link density
  • Regular review sessions

item.title: An Unlinked Note
item.description:
This note demonstrates the orphan detection feature.

No other note links to this page, so it appears on the Orphan Notes page.

Why Orphan Detection Matters

In a Zettelkasten system, value comes from connections. An unlinked note:

  • Cannot be discovered through browsing
  • Doesn’t contribute to the knowledge graph
  • May be forgotten

The orphan detector surfaces these notes so you can decide to:

  1. Link them to relevant notes
  2. Delete them if no longer useful
  3. Develop them into more complete thoughts

This Note’s Purpose

This specific note exists only to demonstrate the orphan detection feature. In a real system, you’d either integrate it or remove it.

item.title: Idea: Why Atomic Notes Work
item.description:
Just realized why [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes]] feel so right:

When I try to write about two ideas in one note, I get stuck. The note never feels complete. But when I split them, each note writes itself.

The constraint isn’t limiting - it’s liberating.

Maybe like how haiku’s strict form produces better poetry than “write whatever you want”?

TODO: Develop this into a permanent note about creative constraints. Link to articles about constraint-based creativity.

Morning

Had the insight about why [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes]] work - captured it in [[Idea: Why Atomic Notes Work]]. The constraint is liberating, not limiting.

Afternoon

Cleaned up some tags. Realized I was using tags when I should be using links. Tags for broad categories, links for specific connections.

Reflection

A week into building this system, patterns are emerging:

  1. [[Spaced Repetition]] happens naturally when you traverse the graph
  2. [[Evergreen Notes]] really do grow - I keep adding to them
  3. The hard part is [[Progressive Summarization|distilling]], not capturing

Morning

Working on [[Evergreen Notes]]. The idea that notes compound in value over time is compelling. Like investments - small consistent additions lead to big results.

Afternoon

Explored the full-page graph view today. Interesting to see clusters forming around [[Note-Taking]] and [[Learning]].

Tasks Done

  • Link spaced repetition to progressive summarization
  • Add literature notes from Ahrens book
  • Create note on retrieval practice

Morning

Re-read [[As We May Think]]. Bush’s 1945 vision is remarkably accurate. We have the tools he imagined - now it’s about using them well.

Afternoon

Added more links between notes. The [[Bidirectional Linking|backlinks]] section is becoming useful - I can see how ideas connect from both directions.

Ideas

  • Should create a note about “reading vs. thinking” - consuming information isn’t the same as processing it
  • The [[Learning|learning MOC]] needs more structure

Morning

Started reading about [[Progressive Summarization]]. The layered approach makes sense - don’t process everything upfront, wait until you need it.

Afternoon

Working on setting up this knowledge base. The [[Note-Taking|graph visualization]] is starting to look interesting now that I have some connected notes.

Evening

Quick thought: the constraint of [[The Atomic Notes Principle|atomic notes]] feels similar to the constraint of daily notes. Both force focus.

item.title: Progressive Summarization
item.description:
Progressive summarization is Tiago Forte’s method for extracting value from notes over time. Instead of processing everything upfront, you distill notes progressively as you use them.

The Layers

Each pass adds a layer of highlighting:

Layer 0: Original content (capture) Layer 1: Bold the most interesting passages Layer 2: Highlight the bolded passages that stand out Layer 3: Write a brief summary at the top Layer 4: Remix into your own original content

item.title: Spaced Repetition
item.description:
Spaced repetition is a learning technique based on the spacing effect: we remember things better when we review them at increasing intervals rather than cramming.

The Science

When you learn something new, the memory decays over time. Each review strengthens the memory and slows the decay rate. By timing reviews just before you’d forget, you maximize retention with minimum effort.

The optimal intervals follow a pattern:

  1. First review: 1 day
  2. Second review: 3 days
  3. Third review: 7 days
  4. Fourth review: 14 days
  5. And so on, roughly doubling each time

Application to Note-Taking

Spaced repetition complements [[Evergreen Notes]] naturally. Each time you revisit a note to add links or refine content, you’re reinforcing that knowledge.

item.title: Bidirectional Linking
item.description:
Bidirectional linking means that when note A links to note B, note B automatically knows about and displays the connection back to A. This simple mechanism transforms how we navigate and discover knowledge.

Why Backlinks Matter

Traditional links are one-way streets. You know where you’re going, but you can’t see where you came from. Backlinks complete the picture.

item.title: Building a Knowledge Graph
item.description:
The knowledge graph visualizes connections between notes. It turns the abstract idea of “linked thinking” into something you can see and explore.

Why Visualize?

Our brains are visual. A list of backlinks tells you what connects, but a graph shows you how the connections form patterns.

How It Works

The graph uses D3.js force simulation. Each note becomes a node; each link becomes an edge.

item.title: Evergreen Notes
item.description:
Evergreen notes are notes designed to grow and improve over time. Unlike fleeting captures or project-specific documentation, evergreen notes are investments in your future thinking.

Characteristics

Concept-oriented: Written about ideas, not sources or events. A note titled “Spaced Repetition” is evergreen; “Notes from Chapter 3” is not.

Densely linked: Connected to many other notes, forming a web of knowledge. Each new connection adds context and value.

Written for yourself: In your own words, reflecting your understanding. Not quotes or summaries, but synthesis.

item.title: The Atomic Notes Principle
item.description:
The atomic notes principle states that each note should contain exactly one idea. This constraint forces clarity and enables powerful connections.

Why Atomicity Matters

When a note contains multiple ideas, linking becomes ambiguous. Does a link point to idea A or idea B? By keeping notes atomic, every link has a clear, unambiguous target.

Atomic notes are:

  • Self-contained: Understandable without context
  • Linkable: Can be connected precisely
  • Reusable: Can appear in multiple contexts
  • Evolvable: Can be refined independently

The Test

Ask yourself: “Can I summarize this note in one sentence?” If you need multiple sentences covering different topics, the note should be split.

item.title: As We May Think
item.description:
In 1945, Vannevar Bush published “As We May Think” in The Atlantic, describing the Memex - a hypothetical device for storing and linking personal knowledge.

The Memex Vision

Bush imagined a desk-sized device containing:

  • Microfilm storage of all books and records
  • A mechanism to add personal annotations
  • The ability to create trails between related items

“The human mind operates by association. With one item in its grasp, it snaps instantly to the next that is suggested by the association of thoughts.”

item.title: How to Take Smart Notes
item.description:
How to Take Smart Notes by SÃ¶nke Ahrens introduces Niklas Luhmann’s Zettelkasten method to a modern audience. Luhmann, a German sociologist, wrote over 70 books and 400 articles using this system.

Key Concepts

The Slip-Box System

Luhmann maintained two slip-boxes:

  1. Bibliographical box: Quick references to sources
  2. Main box: His own ideas and connections

The main box is where the magic happens. Each note is:

  • Written in complete sentences
  • Self-contained and understandable in isolation
  • Connected to existing notes via explicit links

Writing as Thinking

Ahrens argues that writing is not the output of thinking but the medium of thinking. The act of writing forces clarity.

item.title: Flavor Theme
item.description:
Flavor is a Hugo theme built for personal knowledge management. It combines the simplicity of static site generation with powerful features for networked note-taking.

Features

  • Wikilinks: Link notes using [[double brackets]] or shortcodes
  • Backlinks: Automatic detection of pages linking to the current page
  • Knowledge Graph: D3.js visualization of note connections
  • Note Types: Taxonomy for fleeting, literature, permanent, and MOC notes
  • Related Notes: Algorithmic suggestions based on shared links and tags
  • Dark Mode: Automatic theme switching with manual toggle
  • Search: Full-text fuzzy search with Fuse.js

Technical Stack

Built with a modern, minimal stack:

item.title: Personal Knowledge Base
item.description:

Structure

The knowledge base is organized around Maps of Content (MOCs):

Individual notes link freely across these domains, creating a web of interconnected ideas.

item.title: Home Automation
item.description:
A smart home system prioritizing local control, privacy, and reliability.

Philosophy

Local first: Everything runs on local hardware. No cloud dependencies.

Open protocols: Zigbee, MQTT, ESPHome - no proprietary lock-in.

Fail safe: Manual controls always work, even if automation fails.

Stack

Control Center

  • Home Assistant: Central automation hub
  • Mosquitto: MQTT broker for device communication
  • Zigbee2MQTT: Bridge for Zigbee devices

Devices

  • ESPHome: Custom sensors and controllers on ESP32/ESP8266
  • Zigbee: Lights, buttons, sensors from various manufacturers
  • Z-Wave: Some legacy devices

item.title: CLI Notes
item.description:
A fast command-line note-taking tool designed for developers who live in the terminal.

Features

  • Quick capture: notes add "thought about something"
  • Tagging: notes add -t work,ideas "project idea"
  • Search: notes search "keyword"
  • Export: notes export --format markdown

Why CLI?

Sometimes you just want to capture a thought without:

  • Opening a browser
  • Waiting for an app to load
  • Leaving the terminal

CLI Notes keeps you in flow.

Technical Details

Built with Go for fast startup and single-binary distribution. Uses SQLite for local storage - no server required.

item.title: About
item.description:
This is a demo site showcasing the Flavor Hugo theme.

The Theme

Flavor is a minimal Hugo theme with Tailwind CSS and Zettelkasten-inspired knowledge management features. It’s designed for:

  • Personal blogs and websites
  • Digital gardens and knowledge bases
  • Technical documentation
  • Online portfolios

Features Demonstrated

This demo showcases:

Zettelkasten Features

  • Wikilinks: [[double bracket]] syntax and shortcodes
  • Backlinks: Automatic detection of linking pages
  • Knowledge Graph: Interactive D3.js visualization
  • Note Types: Fleeting, literature, permanent, and MOC
  • Related Notes: Algorithmic suggestions

Content Features

  • Articles: Long-form technical content
  • Notes: Atomic knowledge units
  • Projects: Portfolio showcase
  • Search: Fuzzy full-text search

Design Features

  • Dark Mode: Automatic or manual
  • Responsive: Mobile-friendly
  • Accessible: Semantic HTML, ARIA labels
  • Fast: Static generation, minimal JavaScript

Get Started

  1. Clone the theme: git clone https://github.com/a-kostevski/flavor
  2. Copy the example site
  3. Customize hugo.toml
  4. Start writing!

See the README for detailed documentation.
